DataElement.preferredName: Infusion Perfusion Procedure Limb Peak Temperature Celsius Scale Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Value for the highest temperature in Celsius degrees reached within a limb during an isolated limb perfusion (ILP) or isolated limb infusion (ILI) procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Infusion Perfusion Procedure Limb Peak Temperature
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream._Bathing an organ or tissue with a fluid. In regional perfusion, a specific area of the body (usually an arm or a leg) receives high doses of anticancer drugs through a blood vessel. Such a procedure is performed to treat cancer that has not spread._A body region referring to an upper or lower extremity._The most extreme possible amount or value; the highest point._the degree of hotness or coldness of a body or environment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream.:Bathing an organ or tissue with a fluid. In regional perfusion, a specific area of the body (usually an arm or a leg) receives high doses of anticancer drugs through a blood vessel. Such a procedure is performed to treat cancer that has not spread.:A body region referring to an upper or lower extremity.

Concepts.definition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.

The process of flooding fluid through the artery to saturate the surrounding tissue. In regional perfusion, a specific area of the body (usually an arm or a leg) is targeted and high doses of anticancer drugs are flooded through the artery to reach the surrounding tissue and kill as many cancer cells as possible. Such a procedure is performed in cases where the cancer is not thought to have spread past a localized area.
A body region referring to an upper or lower extremity.

Property.preferredDefinition: The most extreme possible amount or value; the highest point.:the degree of hotness or coldness of a body or environment.

Concepts.definition: The most extreme possible amount or value; the highest point.

A measure of the average kinetic energy of a system of particles. Temperature may be quantified, in the context of thermodynamics, as the potential of one system to transfer thermal energy to another system until both systems reach a state of thermal equilibrium.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The temperature scale defined by the values 0 degree Celsius for the freezing point of water and 100 degrees Celsius for the boiling point of water.  The Celsius degree (C) is the same size as a Kelvin and equal to (F - 32)/1.8._A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The temperature scale defined by the values 0 degree Celsius for the freezing point of water and 100 degrees Celsius for the boiling point of water.¿ The Celsius degree (C) is the same size as a Kelvin and equal to (F - 32)/1.8.¿ To convert Celsius to Fahrenheit units, one can use the following formula: (C x 9/5 + 32).:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: The temperature scale defined by the values 0 degree Celsius for the freezing point of water and 100 degrees Celsius for the boiling point of water.  The Celsius degree (C) is the same size as a Kelvin and equal to (F - 32)/1.8.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support Duke University melanoma clinical trial
